context.text: In 1998, the State of California passed the Holocaust Victim Insurance Relief Act which requires any insurance company operating in California to disclose certain information about policies at or any affiliated companies sold in Europe between 1920 and 1945 or else lose its license to do business in the State of California.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The claim rests on two premises, each of which is supported by our cases: the first is that the President has some independent constitutional authority to determine what the nation’s foreign policy should be, the principle established in our President’s recognizing that the President plays the lead role in representing the United States on international issues; the second premise is that state law must yield to the President’s foreign policy if the two are in serious conflict.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The principal authority for that preposition is our decision in Zschernig v. Miller in 1968.

context.speaker: David H. Souter

context.speaker: David H. Souter

context.speaker: David H. Souter

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: In contrast to the President’s endorsement of the International Commission's voluntary approach to disclosure of insurance information, California’s economic compulsion to make disclosure a far more information than the International Commission requires undermines the President’s discretion in dealing with European allies and the choice he has made in exercising it.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The California law also threatens to frustrate the President’s objectives in making it more difficult to persuade foreign companies to participate in voluntary organizations like the International Commission.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Indeed, shortly after the California law was passed, the officials of the Executive Branch wrote to California officials saying that the state law threatened the success of the President’s diplomatic initiatives.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The evidence presented is enough to make clear that the California law interferes with the President’s articulated foreign policy with the consequence that it is preempted.

context.text: --Well... well, I understand that, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Felix Leatherwood
context.text: My position is that even though that law does not exist in California--

context.text: So, again, the states--

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: --No, no, penal judgments, the court said in... in Milwaukee County, have to be enforced, but they... they distinguished at that point, Mr. Chief Justice, the idea that a law itself would have to be in force before it had been reduced to--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Right, but what... what... what is the... I don't want to... I don't want you to get distracted, because I thought Justice Ginsberg and maybe Justice Kennedy and I were driving at the same problem, which is that imagine Nevada v. Hall is good law.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: All right, now, the question comes up, How do you prevent Nevada from going wild?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: All right.

context.text: I thought discovery was--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --Okay.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --interlocutory.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I thought that we couldn't write in an opinion, as Justice Breyer has suggested, because I didn't think that that question was currently reviewable.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: --Well, there's certainly nothing specifically in the question presented about discovery.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: The... the... the... again, to come back to the question presented, because we've discussed a wide range of issues, most of which I don't think are within the question presented, but when we come back to the question presented, the question is basically was the Nevada or the Nevada courts required to dismiss this action on summary judgment because of California's law of immunity?

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: And, in fact, they have become more specific in applying comity, I believe, in saying we want to treat the other sovereign as we do treat ourselves, not just as we want to be treated.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: We are treating the other sovereign the way we treat ourselves.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: What if the... what if the case came, and they didn't do it?

context.text: Justice Breyer's question, how do I fill in the blank?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I... if, let's say, through this intrusive discovery process, systematically applied, they really were interfering with California's taxation, couldn't California bring an original action to enjoin this interference?

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: And, of course, as I've said, I mean, California can try to talk to Nevada and try to reach agreement at a sovereign level about this, or if, in fact... the Full Faith and Credit Clause has a specific express commitment to Congress of the right to declare the effects of other laws.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What would be the underlying--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Underlying--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --substantive law in Justice Souter's proposed original action?

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: The... I suppose, I mean, based on what California has said before... said up to now, it would bring it under the Full Faith and Credit Clause, that it would say that there is some requirement--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, but we wouldn't need an original action for the Full Faith and Credit Clause.

context.speaker: David F. Walbert
context.text: Well, I would say this.

context.speaker: David F. Walbert
context.text: Where you have a real equal opportunity at winning the seat, that is enough.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yes, but that's the... that's the conclusion, and we're... we're looking for some kind of indication at this point of whether that is true.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And the only indication that at least I have and I think that Justice Ginsburg is... is looking at right now are... are the percentage figures, the BVAP percentage figures.

context.speaker: David F. Walbert
context.text: Well, I think this, Your Honor.

context.speaker: David F. Walbert
context.text: I mean, the... the court accepted Dr. Epstein's probability curve all over... any number of times.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That sounds very much like section 2 language.

context.speaker: David F. Walbert
context.text: And... and that's in section 5 under Justice Marshall is all I'm saying, Your Honor, because this issue that is in this case today has never been squarely put before this Court.

context.speaker: David F. Walbert
context.text: But all the prior language of the Court interpreting, where does section 5 kick in when there is still fair, equal districts.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I thought that the Bossier, the two cases, clarified the difference between section 2 and section 5, and what you just read from Justice Marshall sounds to me like the section 2 standard.

context.speaker: David F. Walbert
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Section 5 standard is you start with what you have, you look to see if there's backsliding.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: --in an additional district?

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: --I don't... there was... there was a pair of Senate Districts, not 2, 12, and 26, one of which was reduced sharply in black population--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I have the same... I have the same problem with Justice O'Connor.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I... I thought the case was before us on... on the assumption that there is a likelihood that there will be another black representative from another district--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --Yes, but don't the figures--

context.speaker: E. Marshall Braden
context.text: --whether or not they'll be elected.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --Don't the figures show that some of the districts were way up there before, were... were packed and they reduced them something like 80 percent to 55 or 60?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Doesn't that fit precisely under what Justice Scalia described?

context.speaker: E. Marshall Braden
context.text: Absolutely correct.

context.speaker: E. Marshall Braden
context.text: And in fact, to be candid with you, it's our view as the intervenors... we believe the court actually probably went too low, that they took the numbers down, and frankly, the election results from the last election showed that our argument was vindicated by the failure to elect in certain district candidates of choice.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: With respect to the ability of minority voter’s ability to elect a candidate of choice, Section 5 gives the State some selectability to choose one theory of effective representation over another.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: With respect to the minority groups’ opportunity to participate in a political process, the Court should examine among other things whether the new plan adds or subtracts districts where minority voters can play a substantial even if not decisive role in the electoral process, and whether the representatives elected for majority/minority districts supports the new districting plan.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: We vacate the judgment below and remand the case for the District Court to determine whether Georgia has met its burden approved under the somewhat broader legal standard than District Court employed.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But... but I don't... if you said to a businessperson, this doesn't have standards, such a thing, I think they might laugh and say my job and experience is to select who's better for this slot, so... so I'm not sure of the constitutional relevance of what you say, which seems to me to me to grow out of the nature of the problem.

context.speaker: Kirk O. Kolbo
context.text: Well, again, Justice Breyer, the constitutional relevance derives from the fact that we're talking about a constitutional right here, the use of race, which is not the same thing as--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Yes, yes, but I mean, as Justice Stevens just said, the constitutional problem consists of the injury to your client and that injury is the same irrespective of the precise nature of the standards on the other side.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And... and what I'm sort of struggling for here is I see your point, if you say you cannot use race at all, period.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: No matter what.

context.speaker: Kirk O. Kolbo
context.text: And those rights are the right to equal protection.

context.speaker: Kirk O. Kolbo
context.text: And a mere social benefit that is having more minorities in particular occupations or the schools simply doesn't rise to the level of compelling interest.

context.speaker: Kirk O. Kolbo
context.text: It simply is not... it doesn't remedy a constitutional value, like--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So if the University president or the dean told you just what Justice Breyer said, you would tell them there's... and that we have underrepresentation of minorities, you would tell them there's nothing you can do about it?

context.speaker: Kirk O. Kolbo
context.text: --I would say, Your Honor, that racial preferences are not the answer.

context.speaker: Kirk O. Kolbo
context.text: If there are problems again in not getting a sufficient number of... if minorities are not competing at levels of other racial groups then we should take steps to solve that problem.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Do we... they have rejected what you recited as the ills that follow from this.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Should we shut that from our view at all or should we consider what judges in other places have said on this subject?

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: I submit, Justice Ginsburg that none of those countries has our history, none of those countries has the Fourteenth Amendment, none of those histories has the history of the statements by this Court which has examined the question over and over again that the ultimate damage that is done by racial preferences is such that if there ever is a situation in which such factors must be used that they must be... race neutral means must be used to accomplish those objective, narrow tailoring must be applied, and this... this... these programs fail all of those tests.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: General Olson, do you know whether any of those countries that Justice Ginsburg referred to that have gone down the road of racial preferences, racial entitlements, have ever gotten rid of racial preferences or racial entitlements?

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: There--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Has it been the road to ultimately a color blind society or has it been the road to a society that has percentage entitlements for the various races?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Go ahead.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Are you finished?

context.speaker: John A. Payton
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I wanted to go back to Justice Kennedy's question.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The point system here, does it meet the opinion of Justice Powell in Bakke when that was called for individualized consideration?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now, the concern that it does not, is that you under this system would seem to have the possibility that two students... one is a minority, African American, one is not, majority, and they seem academically approximately the same and now we give the black student 20 points and the white student, let's say, is from the poorest family around and is also a great athlete, and he just can't overcome that 20 points... the best he can do is tie.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Are you finished?

context.speaker: John A. Payton
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I wanted to go back to Justice Kennedy's question.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The point system here, does it meet the opinion of Justice Powell in Bakke when that was called for individualized consideration?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now, the concern that it does not, is that you under this system would seem to have the possibility that two students... one is a minority, African American, one is not, majority, and they seem academically approximately the same and now we give the black student 20 points and the white student, let's say, is from the poorest family around and is also a great athlete, and he just can't overcome that 20 points... the best he can do is tie.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And so that's the argument that this is not individualized consideration.

context.speaker: John A. Payton
context.text: Twelve percent to 17 percent.

context.speaker: John A. Payton
context.text: I'm not saying it's a percent and I'm not saying it's that fixed range, but 12 percent to 17 percent is sort of how it is ranged and that has generated the representation in the small groups that is what is working to achieve some of these educational benefits that we're talking about.

context.speaker: John A. Payton
context.text: But it's not quite that precise as far as how all of this works.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Payton, let me ask Justice O'Connor's question, when does all of this come to an end?

context.speaker: John A. Payton
context.text: I think that we all certainly expect it to come to an end.

context.speaker: John A. Payton
context.text: I think we're all quite surprised if we looked back at Bakke, in 1978, I think all of us would be quite surprised from that vantage point to realize that today in Michigan students live in such segregated circumstances growing up, it's really quite unbelievable.

context.speaker: John A. Payton
context.text: I think they do in all sorts of ways.

context.speaker: John A. Payton
context.text: They are certainly producing black students, white students, Hispanic students, Native American students who go out into our communities and change their communities.

context.text: You may have misunderstood me.

context.text: I mean the... Ms. Mahoney said earlier that the problem of law school admissions, in response to Justice O'Connor, that it was for the elite schools, it was more a problem at the elite schools, when she was talking about Boalt Hall, for example, you meant... you suggested or alluded to in your argument today that, you know, you don't want to choose between being an elite school and the whole diversity issue.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: It... would it be easier to accomplish the latter if the former were adjusted, that is the overall admissions standard?

context.speaker: John A. Payton
context.text: I think that--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The second opinion which I have to announce is in the case of 02-516, Jennifer Gratz versus Lee Bollinger.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Jennifer Gratz and Patrick Hamacher both applied for admission to the University of Michigan's undergraduate College of Literature, Science, and Arts, unlike the law school case which Justice O'Connor just announced.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Both were denied admission.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: They subsequently filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court alleging that the University's use of racial preferences in undergraduate admissions violate Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Section 1981 of Title 42 of U.S. Code.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We hold that Hamacher have standing to seek his perspective relief with respect to the University's continued use of race in admission.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Thus, we turn to the merits of petitioner's claim.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We hold that the University's current policy which distributes 20 points to every underrepresented minority applicant solely because of race is not narrowly tailored to achieve respondents asserted interest in diversity.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In the Bakke case, Justice Powell emphasized the importance of considering each particular applicant as an individual assessing all of the qualities that individual possesses and in turn evaluating that individual's ability to contribute to the unique setting of higher education.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Admissions Program he described did not contemplate that any single characteristic automatically insured a specific and identified contribution to University's diversity.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Instead, each characteristic of an applicant was to be considered in assessing the applicant's entire application.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Instead, each characteristic of an applicant was to be considered in assessing the applicant's entire application.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The current LSA policy clearly fails to provide such individualized review.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The only consideration that a company, the LSA, the mechanized distribution of 20 points to each underrepresented minority applicant is a determination that the applicant is in fact a member of such a group.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Moreover, unlike Justice Powell's discussion where the race of a particular black applicant, as he put it, could be considereed without being decisive, respondents readily conceived that this automatic distribution makes race decisive for virtually every minimally qualified underrepresented minority applicant.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The flagging program does not save this Admissions Program.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This review is the exception and not the rule in the operation of the program and it is only provided after the University automatically distributes points that make race the decisive factor.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The flagging program does not save this Admissions Program.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This review is the exception and not the rule in the operation of the program and it is only provided after the University automatically distributes points that make race the decisive factor.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Finally, we reject the University's argument that administrative challenges make it impractical for the school to use the program upheld in Grutter. That a program capable of providing individualized consideration might presents such challenges does not render constitutional and otherwise problematic system such as Michigan.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: In an opinion filed with the Clerk of the Court today, we affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals, and hold that the Law School's use of race in admissions is narrowly tailored to further a compelling state interest in assembling a diverse student body.

context.text: We last addressed the use of race in University admissions in the landmark Bakke case.

context.text: And there is, in fact, a serious question about the integrity of the court when the composition of the court is simply illegal.

context.speaker: David A. Moran

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia

context.speaker: David A. Moran

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.text: We're all pursuing exactly same thing which I'm having trouble with, and--

context.speaker: David A. Moran
context.text: --First of all, Justice Breyer, he said, I granted the motion.

context.speaker: David A. Moran
context.text: There was not the slightest indication in the Michigan Supreme Court's opinion that it thought it was engaged in fact finding.

context.speaker: David A. Moran
context.text: Nor did this Court think that it was engaged in fact finding in several cases in which this Court has examined arguably ambiguous district court transcripts to determine whether or not an acquittal had been granted, for example, Scott and even more clearly, Sanabria.

context.speaker: David A. Moran
context.text: In Sanabria, this Court had to wade through a difficult record to determine whether or not the district court had, in fact, granted a directed verdict on both theories, numbers theory and horse betting theory.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, let me follow up on an earlier question of Justice Breyer's.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Do you think that if this is true under the Federal system that it was a directed verdict, it must therefore be true under the... under an... under any State system?

context.speaker: Amanda Frost
context.text: There's the fact that Congress said, upon consent, meaning consent must come first.

context.speaker: Amanda Frost
context.text: It makes no sense to say, consent must come first, if what Congress meant was, simply by showing up once the magistrate starts exercising that authority, we are going to consider you to have consented.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Why not?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: If... Justice Kennedy brought up the analogy to personal jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: If one makes a general appearance just by showing up in court, then any question of whether the court would otherwise have jurisdiction is gone, because there is jurisdiction, personal jurisdiction by consent, just by making a general appearance, so why isn't showing up in that magistrate's courtroom, going to trial without objecting, why isn't that equivalent to a general appearance?

context.speaker: Amanda Frost
context.text: Justice Ginsburg, the answer to your question is that there is in the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure Rule 12, which says that showing up will be waiving your right, and here we have a statute that requires consent, and it's important to look at why Congress wanted that.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but if you're saying that that jurisdiction is on the level, as I think you are, on the level with subject matter jurisdiction--

context.speaker: Amanda Frost
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --then it seems to me you've proved too much, because if it were... if Congress were assuming it was on that level, Congress wouldn't have done this in the first place.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You can't consent to subject matter jurisdiction, and you can't consent to it by filing written forms before trial, so we've got to make the assumption, just as Justice Ginsburg did in her question, that we're dealing with an interest which Congress viewed at a very lower level.

context.speaker: Amanda Frost
context.text: I respectfully disagree, Justice Souter, and here's why.

context.speaker: Amanda Frost
context.text: It's not a question of consenting to subject matter jurisdiction, it's a question of what did Congress say are the limits of the magistrate's--

context.speaker: Amanda Frost
context.text: I think if... if the district court here had not designated this magistrate, that is also an error that could not be overlooked.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but I think you're answering a different objection.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I said, why isn't your consent sufficient so that once you give it, you have no further objection, and you said, the answer is, I didn't consent to a trial in which they can sit back and wait and see what happens and then say, oh, we didn't consent, rendering the entire thing a waste of time.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Justice Ginsburg says, yeah, but if we say, they don't have the right to pull their consent if they sat there and implicitly consented, then you don't have that problem at all, and that would be the end of the argument, and I don't think you've answered that.

context.speaker: Amanda Frost
context.text: Yes, I agree, and let me answer... you're very right, Justice Souter, and let me answer the question that I think you both are posing, which is, could a harmless error standard be applied here?

context.speaker: Amanda Frost
context.text: In other words, if it is true that the only right is my client's, and--

context.speaker: Amanda Frost
context.text: --Oh, I saw them as related, because I... if I understood your question correctly, what I thought you were asking was--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --Your answer was, I consented, so far as I was concerned, to be tried.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I didn't consent to give them an option to go through an entire trial and then pull the rug out if they didn't like the result.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Justice Ginsburg's suggestion and my suggestion is, if we... this.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: If we find that an implicit consent on their part is sufficient, they can't pull the rug out, and that would be the end of the issue so far as self protection is concerned, and I don't--

context.speaker: Amanda Frost
context.text: --I agree.
[Laughter]

context.speaker: Amanda Frost
context.text: --Well, respectfully, Your Honor, I think this is related, because what I was trying to say is that while I agree with you that once you say, if these people go forward at trial, they're stuck, then there is no question about, did my client get a raw deal here, because everyone's bound, and they would have been bound if they had lost, so that is why I am going on to the next argument, which is harmless error, and whether or not that would legitimately be something that a court could apply in this situation, and this Court has said, in both it's magistrate judge jurisprudence and also in its Article III jurisprudence--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.text: Section 636(c)(1) of the Federal Magistrate Act of 1979 allows fulltime federal magistrate judges to conduct civil trials as long as the magistrate judge is designated by the District Court for that purpose and is acting upon the consent of the parties.

context.text: While recurring re-litigation in the absence of express written consent would give maximum protection to the litigant’s rights to an Article III judge, it will impose a significant burden on judicial resources and would give undeserving parties a second bite at the apple.

context.speaker: Iva C. Dougherty

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why is that important?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why is it important for drawing a double jeopardy line that in the Poland situation a jury makes a unanimous determination, or in Justice Breyer's hypothetical, a judge that has the power makes the ultimate determination himself?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: If the judgment can otherwise be attacked on the underlying conviction, why should it make a difference for double jeopardy on sentence that the judgment of life rests upon these kinds of determinations rather than the operation of law which we have?

context.speaker: Iva C. Dougherty
context.text: Because an acquittal has always... the definition of acquittal has always been based on a finding of innocence, on a finding that the State hasn't proved its case, and if there are no such findings... and that's why double jeopardy hasn't been applied to traditional sentencing proceedings, and if you don't have those findings, then there's no basis to justify the acquittal, which would bar it under double jeopardy.

context.speaker: Sri Srinivasan
context.text: No, I think if the jury is required to make a unanimous verdict in either direction, and the judge imposes a sentence of life imprisonment because the jury has made a unanimous verdict, that would have--

context.speaker: Sri Srinivasan

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist

context.speaker: Sri Srinivasan

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: Sri Srinivasan
context.text: --Well, I think in that situation we'd have the same answer that we would to Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical, which is that because the defendant has not been afforded an opportunity to obtain finality, then the double jeopardy law would treat that judgment as final, and the State would not be permitted in that situation to revisit the sentencing judgment.

context.speaker: Sri Srinivasan
context.text: But this case is different in a significant respect, because here, Pennsylvania law draws a distinction between a unanimous jury verdict and a hung jury that results in the imposition of a life sentence, and petitioner had the opportunity to obtain a unanimous jury verdict, and, in fact, when the jury initially past its note to the judge indicating that it had reached an impasse, petitioner immediately moved for declaration of a mistrial and discharge of the jury.

context.speaker: Sri Srinivasan
context.text: And in that situation it's clear under double jeopardy law that when the defendant invites the declaration of a mistrial and the discharge of a jury, there's no double jeopardy prohibition against the State's conducting a retrial or, in this case, the State's conducting a new sentencing proceeding.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But isn't the... isn't the only distinction in Justice Stevens' hypothetical between that case... the case that he posits... and this one, the secrecy.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And I don't know why the secrecy should make a difference, and I don't know why you don't answer by saying, Look, what is necessary in order to implicate double jeopardy is the unanimous acquittal by the fact-finder, and if the record does not manifest that unanimous acquittal, then, in fact, there would be no double jeopardy bar to trying him on the sentence again.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why hasn't that got to be your answer?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why hasn't that got to be your answer?

context.speaker: Sri Srinivasan
context.text: Justice Souter, because it depends on whether State law makes unanimity the deciding criterion.

context.speaker: Sri Srinivasan
context.text: If State law does--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, but on Justice Stevens' hypothetical, it does not.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: His hypothetical was, it's just like this case except that there's a secrecy requirement, so we don't know.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And... and all we know is that yes, there ultimately was one or the other condition necessary and sufficient... sufficient, rather... to support the judgment of life, but we don't know which one it was, and I would have thought that on your position you would say unless it affirmatively appears that there was an acquittal by the unanimous jury, there would be no double jeopardy bar.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In this case we consider the legal validity of a rule, a Ninth Circuit Rule that they set forth in a Circuit Case called United States versus Cruz.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Cruz said that a criminal conspiracy ends automatically when it becomes impossible to achieve the conspiracy’s objective, when for example the Government prostrates a drug conspiracy’s objective by seizing the drug that its members have agreed to distribute.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Legal authority outside the Ninth Circuit overwhelmingly supports this view of the law that the Government’s frustration of the conspiracy’s objective does not necessarily prevent prosecution of unknowing conspirators, and in our view, this latter view correctly sets the law.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So, we find the Ninth Circuit’s Cruz rule erroneous.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We reverse the judgment here in so far as it relies upon that rule, and we remand the case for further proceedings.

context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 01-1067, United States versus White Mt. Apache Tribe will be announced by Justice Souter.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: This case comes to us on writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: A 1960 statute declared that the former Fort Apache Military Reservation was held by the United States in trust for the White Mountain Apache Tribe subject to the right of the Secretary of the Interior to use any part of the land in improvements.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The Federal Circuit reversed and remanded on the understanding that in light of the 1960 Act, the Government’s use of the property triggered a common-law trustee’s duty to act reasonably to preserve the property.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: An obligation fairly interpreted as supporting a money damages claim.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: We now affirm.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: As the Government has argued, and as Justice Ginsburg explained a moment ago, the Indian Tucker Act gives the Court of Federal Claims lurisdiction over tribal claims but it creates no substantiate right enforceable against the Government by way of a claim from money damages.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The statute creates a right capable of supporting such a claim only if it can fairly be interpreted as mandating compensation by the Government for damage sustained.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The Act at issue in this case does permit a fair inference that the Government is subject to duties as a trustee and potential liability and damages for breach.

United States v. White Mt. Apache Tribe.speaker: Justice Souter

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Under the terms of this provision, the United States has enjoyed daily occupation of the trust corpus and so has obtained controlled over the property.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Although the 1960 Act does not expressly subject the Government to conservation duties, the fact that the property occupied by the United states is expressly subject to a trust supports a fair inference that an obligation to preserve the property improvements was incumbent on the Government as trustee.

context.text: The Court of Federal Claims does has jurisdiction to determine whether the Government should be liable in damages for breach.
